Sinful Davey is a 1969 adventure/crime/comedy film.  The film, directed by John Huston, is based on the autobiography of David Haggart entitled The Life Of David Haggart. The film, about a Scottish rogue, was filmed in Ireland and consequently much of the cast have Irish brogues instead of the more accurate Scotish accent.

The Seven Deadly Sins have never been so lively! Grave-robbing, Maid-snatching, Jail-breaking, Jewel-thieving, Smuggling, Piracy and Wife-stealing. (Leave it to Davey to invent No. 8!) 

Sinful Davey (1969) is the story of a Scottish scoundrel, so you have to wonder why John Huston chose to film it on Irish locations and in an Irish studio. He says little to illuminate this in his 1980 autobiography, An Open Book, but an answer surely lies in his longtime love of Irish history and values. Huston had Scottish-Irish ancestry and lived in Ireland from 1952 to 1975, although he shot many productions in other countries during that time. When asked why he moved there and even became a citizen of the Irish Republic, he usually talked about how good the countryside was for hunting, and how convenient it was to live in Europe, where many of his movies were shot.

Beyond these practical reasons, Huston felt a deep connection with Irish culture, which gave him a ÃƒÂ¢Ã¢â€šÂ¬Ã…â€œserenity and a tranquility that assuages the spirit,ÃƒÂ¢Ã¢â€šÂ¬Ã‚ï¿½ as he put it in an interview shortly after the rising cost of living made him reluctantly decide to move elsewhere. Even then he remained loyal to his adopted country. ÃƒÂ¢Ã¢â€šÂ¬Ã…â€œI go back to Ireland,ÃƒÂ¢Ã¢â€šÂ¬Ã‚ï¿½ he said, ÃƒÂ¢Ã¢â€šÂ¬Ã…â€œto lick the wounds that have been inflicted on me in the outer world.ÃƒÂ¢Ã¢â€šÂ¬Ã‚ï¿½ Unfortunately for Huston, he acquired a number of wounds in Ireland as well. The critical and commercial failure of Sinful Davey was one of them.

There actually was a Sinful Davey, and HustonÃƒÂ¢Ã¢â€šÂ¬Ã¢â€žÂ¢s movie is based on the memoir this rascal published in Edinburgh in 1821, written by ÃƒÂ¢Ã¢â€šÂ¬Ã…â€œHimself, While Under Sentence of DeathÃƒÂ¢Ã¢â€šÂ¬Ã‚ï¿½ and grandiosely titled The Life of David Haggart, Alias John Wilson, Alias John Morison, Alias Barney McCoul, Alias John McColgan, Alias Daniel OÃƒÂ¢Ã¢â€šÂ¬Ã¢â€žÂ¢Brien, Alias The Switcher. The bookÃƒÂ¢Ã¢â€šÂ¬Ã¢â€žÂ¢s frontispiece is a drawing of Haggart sitting on a bench in his death-row cell, one leg tied to the floor with a lengthy rope, pen and ink on a shelf nearby. He appears to be quite content, and looks very little like John Hurt, who plays him in the movie. He was executed on July 18, 1821, for ÃƒÂ¢Ã¢â€šÂ¬Ã…â€œthe murder of the late Thomas Morrin, turnkey in the jail of Dumfries,ÃƒÂ¢Ã¢â€šÂ¬Ã‚ï¿½ according to the preface of his book; but in prison he expressed remorse for his crimes, the preface adds, and ÃƒÂ¢Ã¢â€šÂ¬Ã…â€œleft the world a sincere penitent.ÃƒÂ¢Ã¢â€šÂ¬Ã‚ï¿½

HustonÃƒÂ¢Ã¢â€šÂ¬Ã¢â€žÂ¢s movie begins at about the time the real Haggart was waiting for the noose. Davey is in the army when we first meet him, marching in formation and beating a bass drum. But military discipline is definitely not for him; instead, his ambition is to commit as many sins as his father did before getting hanged for a botched robbery at 21. Deserting the corps by jumping off a bridge and floating away in his drum, Davey hooks up with a pickpocket named MacNab, and escapades galore soon follow, ranging from robbery to seduction. HeÃƒÂ¢Ã¢â€šÂ¬Ã¢â€žÂ¢s always in some kind of trouble, and while he sometimes escapes on his own, other times heÃƒÂ¢Ã¢â€šÂ¬Ã¢â€žÂ¢s bailed out by Annie, a childhood friend who quietly loves him and wishes heÃƒÂ¢Ã¢â€šÂ¬Ã¢â€žÂ¢d get religion and settle down.

A turning point comes when Davey meets the Duke of Argyll, the very man who had his father hanged. Davey ingratiates himself with the duke and duchess, pulls off a heist during their fancy-dress ball, gets caught when Annie foils his plan for his own good, and runs for his life in the most elaborate of the movieÃƒÂ¢Ã¢â€šÂ¬Ã¢â€žÂ¢s many chases. Like the real Davey, he winds up in the death house; but Huston grants him a last-minute getaway, and in the end it looks like he might possibly settle down with Annie after all.

Sinful Davey has an enjoyable cast, energetically headed by Hurt, who appears to be having a great time even when the story gets so far-fetched that even his fine talent canÃƒÂ¢Ã¢â€šÂ¬Ã¢â€žÂ¢t make it believable. Among the veteran British actors on hand are Ronald Fraser as MacNab the pickpocket, Pamela Franklin as loyal Annie, Nigel Davenport as a constable on DaveyÃƒÂ¢Ã¢â€šÂ¬Ã¢â€žÂ¢s trail, inimitable Robert Morley as the good-natured duke, and Donal McCann, who would later deliver a superb performance in HustonÃƒÂ¢Ã¢â€šÂ¬Ã¢â€žÂ¢s last film, The Dead (1987), as another aristocrat who crosses DaveyÃƒÂ¢Ã¢â€šÂ¬Ã¢â€žÂ¢s path. They do what they can to make the movie work, and Huston kicks in as much action, color, and buffoonery as the screen will hold, helped by two gifted cinematographers, Freddie Young and Edward Scaife, and a lot of Irish scenery. In the end, though, James R. WebbÃƒÂ¢Ã¢â€šÂ¬Ã¢â€žÂ¢s screenplay is too patchy and episodic to gather much momentum, and the storyÃƒÂ¢Ã¢â€šÂ¬Ã¢â€žÂ¢s sheer silliness eventually catches up with it, making the whole affair seem more frantic than funny.

I suspect Sinful Davey was inspired less by HaggartÃƒÂ¢Ã¢â€šÂ¬Ã¢â€žÂ¢s memoir than by the phenomenal success of Tony RichardsonÃƒÂ¢Ã¢â€šÂ¬Ã¢â€žÂ¢s picaresque Tom Jones (1963), based on Henry FieldingÃƒÂ¢Ã¢â€šÂ¬Ã¢â€žÂ¢s eighteenth-century novel, six years earlier. In his New York Times review of Sinful Davey, critic Vincent Canby mischievously speculated that United Artists agreed to finance it because they thought it came from the author of Tom Jones, not the screenwriter of Guns for San Sebastian (1968). Canby places Sinful Davey into HustonÃƒÂ¢Ã¢â€šÂ¬Ã¢â€žÂ¢s ÃƒÂ¢Ã¢â€šÂ¬Ã…â€œtired period,ÃƒÂ¢Ã¢â€šÂ¬Ã‚ï¿½ and Huston might not have disagreed. ÃƒÂ¢Ã¢â€šÂ¬Ã…â€œI made a series of films between 1968 and 1973,ÃƒÂ¢Ã¢â€šÂ¬Ã‚ï¿½ he wrote in An Open Book, ÃƒÂ¢Ã¢â€šÂ¬Ã…â€œthat were either outright failures or, at best, only moderately successful.ÃƒÂ¢Ã¢â€šÂ¬Ã‚ï¿½ The first was Sinful Davey and the last was The MacKintosh Man (1973), after which The Man Who Would Be King (1975) ended the losing streak by becoming a smash hit. Of these, only Fat City (1972) has been substantially upgraded by critics in later years, although Huston authority John McCarty makes a case for Sinful Davey as a savvy reflection on youth during the tumultuous 1960s. Calling it ÃƒÂ¢Ã¢â€šÂ¬Ã…â€œa mordant black comedy about crime and criminals that harks back to HustonÃƒÂ¢Ã¢â€šÂ¬Ã¢â€žÂ¢s Beat the Devil (1953) and looks forward to PrizziÃƒÂ¢Ã¢â€šÂ¬Ã¢â€žÂ¢s Honor (1985),ÃƒÂ¢Ã¢â€šÂ¬Ã‚ï¿½ McCarty argues in The Films of John Huston that its humor simply had too much ÃƒÂ¢Ã¢â€šÂ¬Ã…â€œsubtletyÃƒÂ¢Ã¢â€šÂ¬Ã‚ï¿½ to be detected by critics and audiences.

Huston didnÃƒÂ¢Ã¢â€šÂ¬Ã¢â€žÂ¢t accept all the blame when Sinful Davey flopped. ÃƒÂ¢Ã¢â€šÂ¬Ã…â€œThe picture was a light-hearted rompÃƒÂ¢Ã¢â€šÂ¬Ã‚Â¦and, I thought, an altogether delightful affair,ÃƒÂ¢Ã¢â€šÂ¬Ã‚ï¿½ he wrote. Then he handed it to executive producer Walter Mirisch and was ÃƒÂ¢Ã¢â€šÂ¬Ã…â€œaghastÃƒÂ¢Ã¢â€šÂ¬Ã‚ï¿½ when he saw it again. Mirisch had ÃƒÂ¢Ã¢â€šÂ¬Ã…â€œgiven full sway to his creative impulses,ÃƒÂ¢Ã¢â€šÂ¬Ã‚ï¿½ Huston complained, making the story a flashback by transferring a scene from the end to the beginning, and adding a ÃƒÂ¢Ã¢â€šÂ¬Ã…â€œdreadful narrationÃƒÂ¢Ã¢â€šÂ¬Ã‚ï¿½ to boot. ÃƒÂ¢Ã¢â€šÂ¬Ã…â€œWhat was rather blithe and unserious became clotted and cluttered and distasteful,ÃƒÂ¢Ã¢â€šÂ¬Ã‚ï¿½ he told a biographer. Mirisch, meanwhile, told the same biographer that Huston had missed a couple of preview screenings where people streamed for the exits, forcing him to make it ÃƒÂ¢Ã¢â€šÂ¬Ã…â€œmore accessible and less confusing.ÃƒÂ¢Ã¢â€šÂ¬Ã‚ï¿½ When that didnÃƒÂ¢Ã¢â€šÂ¬Ã¢â€žÂ¢t work, UA yanked it from release after a week.

Whatever the reasons, Sinful Davey was a box-office fiasco that nobody has particularly wanted to own. But itÃƒÂ¢Ã¢â€šÂ¬Ã¢â€žÂ¢s also an interesting document from HustonÃƒÂ¢Ã¢â€šÂ¬Ã¢â€žÂ¢s tired period, showing what can happen when a great director and a major studio clash over a project that was probably fated from the beginning not to click.
